questions.question:
Question 1: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. He had a bout of streptococcal sore 
throat infection two weeks back. His ESR on admission was 80mm/hr and fever 3€°C. What 
is the mechanism of tissue injury in this condition?

options.c: Type II and type III hypersensitivity
options.d: Type II and type IV hypersensitivity

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with polyarthritis (1 major) along with fever and ESR elevated (2 
minor) is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity. This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis 
or, less commonly, skin infections. The antibodies to streptococcal cell-wall antigen cross-react 
with myocardial antigen resulting in macrophage activation and inflammation. Acute rheumatic carditis is a common manifestation of active RF and may progress over time to 
chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD), mainly manifesting as valvular abnormalities. Damage to 
heart tissue may be caused by a combination of antibody and T-cell-mediated reactions. 758 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which is the least commonly affected heart valve in acute rheumatic fever?
questions.explanation: The least commonly affected valve in acute rheumatic fever is the pulmonary valve. The most commonly affected valve is the mitral valve.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 45-year-old woman died due to cardiac failure. On autopsy, on the mitral valve, small warty 
vegetations were present along the lines of closure. There were also irregular thickenings in 
the left atrium. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the gross findings seen are diagnostic of rheumatic heart disease. Inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves results in fibrinoid necrosis within the 
cusps or tendinous cords. Overlying these necrotic foci and along the lines of closure are small (1 
to 2 mm) warty vegetations. Subendocardial lesions, exacerbated by regurgitant jets, can induce irregular thickenings called 
MacCallum plaques, usually in the left atrium. 759 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnoea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial 
hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most 
likely diagnosis based on the given HPE image?
questions.explanation:
The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease. Aschoff's bodies have the following components: • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages • Abundant cytoplasm • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages • T-cells 760 
Sold by @itachibot • Plasma cells

Question 7: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was 
admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following 
admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of 
these findings? 754 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance in rheumatic 
heart disease. It is due to calcification and fibrosis. Rheumatic heart disease is also associated with subendocardial irregular thickenings known 
as McCallum plaques, as shown below. 762 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is implicated in acute infective endocarditis?
questions.explanation:
Acute infective endocarditis is due to infection by highly virulent organisms like Staphylococcus 
aureus. It results in rapidly necrotizing and destructive lesions. Infective endocarditis is classified into acute and subacute forms. • Acute - infection of a previously normal heart valve by a highly virulent organism • Subacute - infection in previously deformed valves by organisms of lower virulence (S.viridans, 
S. epidermidis, HACEK)

questions.question:
Question 9: A 50-year-old man with severe rheumatic mitral stenosis underwent prosthetic mitral valve 
insertion. In the first 2 months following surgery, he is at the highest risk of infection with 
which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation:
Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (like S. epidermidis). The following organisms are implicated in infective endocarditis following prosthetic valve 
surgery: • Early (< 2 months) - Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis • Intermediate (2-12 months) and late (> 12 months): • Streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus - more common • Enterococci and Staphylococcus epidermidis

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old man presented with a high-grade fever, chills, and breathlessness for 4 days. 
He has no other known medical conditions but has a history of IV drug abuse. On 
examination, the following painful lesions were noted and a regurgitant murmur was heard 
on auscultation. All of the following are minor criteria for diagnosis of this condition except: 755 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
763 
Sold by @itachibot The given features and the image showing painful Osler nodes are suggestive of infective 
endocarditis. Echo showing a valve-related mass is a major criterion according to Duke’s criteria. Infective endocarditis (IE) is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium. 
The aorta, aneurysms, other blood vessels, and prosthetic devices can also become infected. Most 
infections are bacterial. Vegetations on heart valves are the classic hallmark of IE. They are friable, bulky, potentially 
destructive lesions. They contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria, or other organisms. The 
mitral valve is most commonly involved. Complications of infective endocarditis: • Cardiac complications - valvular insufficiency or stenosis, myocardial ring abscess, suppurative 
pericarditis • Embolic complications - left-sided (brain, spleen, kidney) or right-sided lesion (lung infarct and 
abscess) • Renal complications - embolic infarcts, focal (more common) or diffuse glomerulonephritis (less 
common)

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke’s criteria?

options.a: Single positive blood culture for HACEK group is a major criterion
options.b: Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetti is a major criterion
options.d: Documentation of four minor criterion allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.explanation:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to 
establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old woman presented with chest pain and breathlessness for 1 month. Examination 
revealed a regurgitant murmur. Transesophageal echocardiography revealed vegetations on 
both sides of mitral valve leaflets. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with vegetations on both sides of valve leaflets is suggestive 
of Libman–Sacks endocarditis. It is a feature of systemic lupus erythematosus. The vegetations in this condition have the following features: • Small - 1 to 4 mm in diameter • Single or multiple • Sterile, pinkish vegetations • May be located on both sides valve leaflets • Associated with intense valvulitis - characterized by fibrinoid necrosis Mitral valve is more frequently involved and regurgitation is the usual functional abnormality.

questions.question: Question 13: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition?
questions.explanation:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis. 764 
Sold by @itachibot Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on 
heart valves. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, 
the right heart valves may be involved. Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often 
occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the 
presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

questions.question: Question 14: Match the following morphology of vegetations with the conditions in which they are found.
questions.explanation:
The rightly matched vegetations with the conditions that they are seen are as follows: 1-C, 2-A, 
3-D, 4-B Rheumatic heart disease often presents with rheumatic fever phase where small, warty 1- 2 mm 
vegetations, also called veruccae, extend along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets. The 
cardinal anatomical changes of the mitral valve in chronic RHD are: • Leaflet thickening • Commissural fusion and shortening • Thickening and fusion of the tendinous chords Infective endocarditis has large, irregular, friable masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto 
the chordae. These vegetations can be single or multiple and may involve one or more 
valves. They are potentially destructive lesions and contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria or 
other organisms. They can erode into the underlying myocardium and produce a ring abscess. 
They are prone to embolisations, resulting in abscess formation wherever they lodge due to the 
presence of virulent organisms. Thus, it may lead to sequelae like septic infarcts or mycotic 
aneurysms. Subacute infective endocarditis contains less destructive vegetations. They contain granulation 
tissue at their bases indicative of healing. Fibrosis, calcification and a chronic inflammatory 
infiltrate can develop over the time. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by one or more small, 1-5 mm, sterile 
vegetations which are usually attached at the line of closure. They are seen associated with 
hypercoagulable states like chronic DIC or malignancy. They are loosely attached to the 
underlying valve and are non-destructive in nature. They do not cause any inflammatory reaction 
but they can be a source of systemic embolisation. Libman-Sack's endocarditis has small- or medium-sized, 1- 4 mm, sterile vegetations associated 
with systemic lupus erythematosus. They may be present on one or both the sides of the leaflets, 
on the valve surface, chordae or anywhere on the endocardium. These vegetations develop due to 
immune complex deposition and complement activation. They cause intense valvulitis resulting in 
fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance. Persistent injury to the valves can result in scarring and 
leaflet fusion.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not true about non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis?
questions.explanation:
765 
Sold by @itachibot Vegetations in non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) are of 1 to 5 mm size. NBTE is seen in patients with debilitating conditions such as cancer and sepsis or systemic 
hypercoagulable states. Hence it is also called marantic endocarditis. There is the deposition of small sterile thrombi loosely attached to the leaflets of cardiac valves. 
They form single or multiple vegetations along the lines of closure of the leaflets or cusps. They 
are non-invasive and do not elicit an inflammatory reaction. It can be a source of systemic emboli. 766 
Sold by @itachibot Glomerular Diseases
